awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Boundaries to Create and Control Pathways for Photomechanical Actuation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports fundamental research into new ways to hold and constrain liquid crystal elastomers that will cause thin sheets to change shape in discrete steps as the sheets are illuminated.  Liquid crystal elastomers are a class of polymers that can be tailored to undergo changes in shape when they are illuminated with light, thereby enabling the direct conversion of light into directed mechanical work. An important advantage of using light is that wiring, circuitry, and mechanical contacts are not needed; devices made of these materials can be operated remotely.  This property can enable applications in a range of technologies, including light-operated microsurgical tools, display technologies integrated with touch feedback, and robotics that harness light for manipulation.  However, the mechanical force generated by these materials is small and the shape change during irradiation with light is difficult to control. The new shape change mechanisms will simultaneously generate fast response times and large forces during the transition between the shapes.  Therefore, the results of this research can enable new device architectures and bring these materials closer to widespread application, thereby benefitting the US economy and society. Outreach to underrepresented K-12 students through local Pittsburgh organizations will also be integrated with the research program.
 
Light-driven shape change observed in liquid crystal elastomers can enable a class of next-generation of remotely-driven actuators.  This research will explore the interplay between the photomechanical adaptivity and localized constraints applied at the boundary.  In particular, this interplay triggers a cascade of discrete transitions from a prior flat state into non-self-similar shapes. Integrated experiments and modeling will be used to understand the interactions between microstructural heterogeneity, boundary conditions, material anisotropy and photostrains on the emergent multimorphism and actuation.  The resulting core contribution to mechanics will be the deeper fundamental understanding of the interplay between instabilities and boundary conditions in two-dimensional objects with complex curvature and heterogeneity, using shell and membrane theories from mechanics.  The research tasks include synthesis of thin-film specimens, characterization of light-induced mechanical deformation, development of mathematical models, and numerical and analytical analysis of the models.  The feedback between experiment and theory will enable the formulation of predictive and accurate models, as well as provide physics-based guidance to the experiments.

por.por_cntn:
This project demonstrated the utilization of light powered actuators, whose responses compete favorably against traditional actuators to set the stage for photomechanical machines. These systems are envisioned to be composed from nominally passive materials without onboard power or innervated components, which can be impelled into actuation, remotely. The material system that harnesses photons to create mechanical work is characterized by light-switchable molecules that are orientationally aligned in a polymer network (liquid crystalline polymers: LCP). The rate at which photons switch the state of these molecules determines the rate of the actuation. The orientational order dictates the principal strains of the light-driven mechanical distortion. Typically, these photomechanical actuators are slender (10's of micrometers thick) and are not capable of actuation metrics that compare with say, electrical systems. This is because the absorption of the photons, which are transduced into mechanical work by the LCP occurs over micrometer length-scales. As such, the work is generated via bending of slender structures. Low-stiffness actuators cannot present a pronounced torque content.

We studied the non-linear mechanics of shells to convert photons into work/torque-dense actuation. The focus was on understanding how photomechanical bending in shell-like geometries leads to magnified actuation profiles. The effect of geometry and the role of confinement at the periphery of these actuators was of particular interest (Figure 1). Monolithic shells transform upon irradiation into hinge-like creases separating two transversely curved (developable) shells. Gaussian curvature (stretch) is localized at the crease. The two curved segments inherit high bending stiffness from their curvature (i.e., are geometrically stiffened). The actuation resulting from such structural transformation is characterized by ms-timescales and work-content is comparable to that of electromechanical systems. We developed models to characterize the interplay of strain gradients from the absorption of the light, the effect of molecular order and the role of geometry/confinement in generating the unusual actuation profiles (Figure 1). This grant also supported studies into the effect of composition and molecular structure on the performance of LCP. Pathways emerge for engineering the material across length-scales to access a trade space of responses to stimuli.

Such actuators present a design motif that can be extended to a range of stimuli-responsive materials (thermal, electrical, magnetic, chemical). Buckling of shells is a broad design space, wherein bending strains in slender structures can be magnified into actuation profiles that are relevant to practical applications. This research holds implications for envisioning a new class of optically driven actuators that can be deployed at a range of length-scales to power actuators and drive the motility of soft robots (Figure 2).
